org.orgName: Western District Court of Washington, Northern Division.

body.p: K. Gregory and seven others filed a petition praying a writ of habeas corpus alleging that they are in good faith seeking admission into the United States to make the United States their permanent hom; that they do not come within any of the classes prohibited admission. A show cause order was issued and the Commissioner of Immigration made return setting forth, in substance, that the petitioners sout admission and were held for special inquiry by the immigrant inspector and a board of special inquiry was organized as provided by law, and:

The petitioners move that they be forwith discharged, for the fo reason (1) that the return shows thtat they are detained and restrained of their liberty for unlawful reasonas and contrary to the statutes in shuch cases made and provided; (2) that the special examining board and the Secretary of Commerce and Labor and said Commissioner exceeded their authority and jurisdiction; (3) that the alleged reasons for detaining said petitioners are irrelevant, immaterial and not support by evidence, and are frivolous and sham; (4) that said petitioners had all the personal qualifications required of them by the statutes, and to entitle them to immediate and unconditional discharge.

jurisdiction of this court is limited to ascertaining whether the petitioners were denied a hearing, and if a hearing has been accorded, the court is precluded from a re-examination of the issue presented, merely because it is contended that the conclusion of the immigration officers based upon the testimony was wrong. In the Mooa Singh case a trial was had, and the conclusion of the examining board was that the alien be excluded from admission under the laws of the United States. The conclusion of the board found delinquency in the eprsonal qualifications of the applicants which borught the withint the exclusion provisions act. This court connot examine into the testimony produced upon the hearing in this case before the special examining board, nor enter upon a re-examination of the facts. This court is bound by the facts as found by the board of sepcia inquiry. and the facts as found being the qualifications under the provision of the exclsion act.

Are the petitioners qualified to enter under the findings of the board, and is the act of the Board beyond its jurisdiction, and does the personal condition of teh applicants, as found, preclude their exclusions?
Section 1 of the Immigration Act, of Feb. 20, 1907, reads:
"That they shall be levied, collected and paid a tax of $4 for every alien entering the United States."
Sec. 2 of said act, provides who are excluded anyone who are "perceived likely to become a public charge"
A right of appeal from the decision of this board is denited by the provisions of Sec. 25 of the act, as follows:
"But nothing in this section shall admit of any appeal in the case of an alien rejected as provided for in Sec. 10 fo this act."

"...Immigration officers shall have power to administer oaaths, and to take and consider evidence thouching the right of any alien to enter the United States, and where such action is necessary to make a written record of such evidence."

A provision for the punishment of persons who shall knowingly or wilfully give false oaths or swear to any false statement is made, and it is also provided that the decision of such officer in admitting an alien shall be subject to challenge by in other officer, and such challenge shall operate to take the alien whose right to land is challenged before a board of special inquiry for its investigation. If is further provided:

"Every such alien who may not appear to the examining immigrant inspector at the port of arrival to be clearly and beyond doubt entitled to land shall be detained for examination in relation thereto by a board of special inquiry."

"Sec. 25...All hearings before boards shall be separate and the decision of any two of the baord shall prevail; but either the alien or any dissenting member of said board may appeal
to q the secretary of labor.....that in every case where an alien is excluded from admission into the United States under any law or treaty now existing or hereafter made, the decision of the appropriate immigration officers, if adverse to the admission of such alien shall be final, unless reversed on appeal to the secretary of labor."

"That any alien liable to be excluded because likely to become a public charge, or because of physical disability other than tuberculosis or a loathsome or dangerous contagious disease may, if otherwise admissible, nevertheless be admitted in the discretion of the Secretary of Labor upon the giving of a suitable and proper bond or undertaking,

Under Sec. 26 "An alien likely to become a public charge is excluded", and under Sec. 25, the decision of the board of special inquiry is final. While the findings of the board with relation to the petiitoners seem to eliminate all physical and mental deficiencies legslated against, by the conclusions which follow in the construction of this statute, in the absence of an expressed or implied intent as to the meaning of the prase "liable to become a public charge, w it be said that the expression should apply to one or more of the other specific reasons or cause for exclusion or all of them taken together, and which have not developed to the stage to specifically identity on be off sufficient emphasis to demonstarte physical or mental condition, In the consideration of Sec. 26 fo this act making "liable to become a public charge" a specific objection in connection with all of the other specific grounds for exclusion fo the applicant, the conclusion would seem to be by this expression, that the immigratn officers are authorized to take into consideration the general conditions as applied to the applicant, his ability to meet conditions and perform such labor as the new environment and circumstances require, his ability to amalgamate and conform to the
